segments.text: From BBC Learning English this is learning English from the news our podcast about the news headlines in this program is rail Iran strikes the conflict continues
Hello, I'm Phil and I'm Georgie in this program
We look at one big news story and the vocabulary in the headlines that will help you understand it
You can find all the vocabulary and headlines from this episode as well as a worksheet on our website
BBCLearningEnglish.com
So, let's hear more about this story
Israel launched an attack on Iran last Friday targeting nuclear and military facilities
The strikes killed several senior Iranian military commanders and Iranian nuclear scientists
Iran then retaliated with missile attacks targeting Israel
Iran's health ministry said at least
224 people have been killed in the Israeli strikes while Israel says Iranian attacks have killed 24 people
Let's have our first headline
Iran launches new missile barrage Israel claims assassination of top general and that's from the Palestine Chronicle
And that headline again from the Palestine Chronicle
Iran launches new missile barrage Israel claims assassination of top general
This headline is about missile strikes by Iran against Israel in response to Israel strikes against Iran
Which began on Friday and Israel's killing of a senior military official
We're looking at this word barrage Iran launches new missile barrage
What is a barrage?
Well, the specific use in the context of war is a heavy and continuous use of things like guns or bombs
So, a missile barrage means a country is sending lots of missiles at once
Now, this is obviously a serious use
But we can also use a barrage of something in more everyday context to mean a large amount of something that comes all at once
For example, the new employee sent her boss a barrage of questions via email
Yes, or I turned my phone off last night and woke up to a barrage of text messages
Whether it's being used literally or metaphorically
Barrage has this sense that it's an overwhelming amount of something. It's too much all at once
So it often seems quite negative
We've heard a barrage a large amount of something that comes all at once
For example, the TV show received a barrage of complaints after the presenter made an offensive comment
This is learning English from the news from BBC learning English
We're talking about the Israel Iran strikes
As we've mentioned, Israel strikes targeted Iran's nuclear and military facilities
satellite images have shown us that the strikes have damaged structures at two missile sites as well as an airport runway
Let's have another headline and this is from CNN
Israel strikes zeroed in on Iran's nuclear program
How much damage was done and that headline again Israel strikes zeroed in on Iran's nuclear program
How much damage was done and that is from CNN
So this headline is about those Israeli strikes against Iran's nuclear program
This time we're looking at this phrase zero in on what can you tell us
So this is another phrase which has a specific military meaning and more everyday meaning as well
So in this context, it's about aiming a weapon at a particular target
Israel strikes are aiming at Iran's nuclear program
They've zeroed in on it according to the headline
In a more everyday sense, zero in on means to focus all your attention on something
For example, imagine you're in a work meeting
Everyone is sharing lots of ideas but you need to focus on one solution and work on it
Yes, you might say
Okay, let's zero in on Beth's idea and come up with a plan
We've had zero in on focus all your attention on something
For example, the government has said they will zero in on youth unemployment this year
It's their main focus
This is learning English from the news our podcast about the news headlines today
Our story is Israeli Iran strikes shortly after the start of the Israel Iran strikes
There was a G7 summit in Canada
Emitting between seven major industrialized countries
U.S. President Donald Trump left early
France is President Emmanuel Macron said Trump did this to work on a ceasefire deal between Israel and Iran
But Trump denied there was any connection
And we have a headline about this it's from France
Trump says early G7 exit nothing to do with Macron's remarks on Israel Iran ceasefire offer
that headline again
Trump says early G7 exit nothing to do with Macron's remarks on Israeli Iran ceasefire offer and that's from France 24
So this headline says Trump's exit has nothing to do with a ceasefire between Iran and Israel and we're looking at this phrase to do with
to do with three words that everyone knows
But together the phrase is a bit strange isn't it yes to do with means about
or connected to and here it says nothing to do with which means it's not connected to
So Trump said that his early exit is not connected with a ceasefire it's nothing to do with a ceasefire
Okay another example this podcast is about the news it has nothing to do with cooking
It's all to do with the news headlines and vocabulary
That's right so we can add words to to do with nothing to do with
all to do with something to do with everything to do with
And you can hear to do with in combination with has has got and is
Yeah this is a really useful phrase isn't it we use it a lot
in everyday speech now my laptop hasn't been working very well today yeah neither is mine
I think it's something to do with the new software yeah it's got nothing to do with the Wi-Fi because my phone's working fine
We've had to do with about or connected to for example I'm not sleeping very well lately
I think it's something to do with the heat
That's it for this episode of learning English from the news we'll be back next week with another news story
If you've enjoyed this program try the worksheet on our website to test what you've learnt
BBCLearningEnglish.com

Hello I'm Phil and I'm Georgie.
In this program we look at one big news story and the vocabulary in the headlines that will help you understand it.
You can find all the vocabulary and headlines from this episode as well as a worksheet on our website.
BBCLearningEnglish.com
So let's hear more about this story.
Israel launched an attack on Iran last Friday, targeting nuclear and military facilities.
The strikes killed several senior Iranian military commanders and Iranian nuclear scientists.
Iran then retaliated with missile attacks targeting Israel.
Iran's health ministry said at least 224 people have been killed in the Israeli strikes.
While Israel says Iranian attacks have killed 24 people.
Let's have our first headline.
Iran launches new missile barrage.
Israel claims assassination of top general and that's from the Palestine Chronicle.
And that headline again from the Palestine Chronicle.
Iran launches new missile barrage.
Israel claims assassination of top general.
This headline is about missile strikes by Iran against Israel.
In response to Israel strikes against Iran which began on Friday.
And Israel's killing of a senior military official.
We're looking at this word barrage.
Iran launches new missile barrage.
What is a barrage?
Well, the specific use in the context of war is a heavy and continuous use of things like guns or bombs.
So a missile barrage means a country is sending lots of missiles at once.
Now, this is obviously a serious use.
But we can also use a barrage of something in more everyday context.
To mean a large amount of something that comes all at once.
For example, the new employee sent her boss a barrage of questions via email.
Yes, or I turned my phone off last night and woke up to a barrage of text messages.
Whether it's being used literally or metaphorically,
barrage has this sense that it's an overwhelming amount of something.
It's too much all at once.
So it often seems quite negative.
We've heard barrage a large amount of something that comes all at once.
For example, the TV show received a barrage of complaints after the presenter made an offensive comment.
This is learning English from the news from BBC Learning English.
We're talking about the Israel Iran strikes.
As we've mentioned, Israel strikes targeted Iran's nuclear and military facilities.
Satellite images have shown us that the strikes have damaged structures at two missile sites as well as an airport runway.

How much damage was done?

How much damage was done? And that is from CNN.
So this headline is about those Israeli strikes against Iran's nuclear program.
This time we're looking at this phrase zero in on.
What can you tell us?
So this is another phrase which has a specific military meaning and more everyday meaning as well.
So in this context, it's about aiming a weapon at a particular target.
Israel strikes our aiming at Iran's nuclear program.
They've zeroed in on it according to the headline.
In a more everyday sense, zero in on means to focus all your attention on something.
For example, imagine you're in a work meeting.
Everyone is sharing lots of ideas but you need to focus on one solution and work on it.
Yes, you might say, OK, let's zero in on Beth's idea and come up with a plan.
We've had zero in on focus all your attention on something.
For example, the government has said they will zero in on youth unemployment this year.
It's their main focus.

Our podcast about the news headlines.
Today, our story is Israeli Iran strikes.
Shortly after the start of the Israel Iran strikes,
there was a G7 summit in Canada, a meeting between seven major industrialised countries.

So this headline says Trump's exit has nothing to do with a ceasefire between Iran and Israel.

But together, the phrase is a bit strange, isn't it?
Yes.

Or connected to.
And here it says nothing to do with, which means it's not connected to.
So Trump said that his early exit is not connected with a ceasefire.
It's nothing to do with a ceasefire.
Okay, another example, this podcast is about the news.
